document.masterDocTitle: A contribution to understanding the morphology of the genus Anthroherpon (= Parantrophilon syn. nov.) and new combination for a species from the Balkan Peninsula (Insecta, Coleoptera, Leiodidae, Cholevinae, Leptodirini)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A contribution to understanding the morphology of the genus Anthroherpon (= Parantrophilon syn. nov.) and new combination for a species from the Balkan Peninsula (Insecta, Coleoptera, Leiodidae, Cholevinae, Leptodirini)

mods:name.mods:affiliation: Biospeleologica Slovaca, Letná 16, SK- 040 01, Košice, Slovakia. Croatian Biospeleological Society, Rooseveltov trg 6, 10 000 Zagreb, Croatia. davidceplik @ yahoo. com; https: // orcid. org / 0000 - 0003 - 4784 - 0464

Department of Entomology, National Museum, Natural History Museum, Cirkusová 1740, CZ- 193 00 Praha 9 - Horní Počernice, Czech Republic. peterclaviger @ gmail. com; https: // orcid. org / 0000 - 0001 - 5060 - 0811

subSubSection.paragraph:
Material studied.
Type locality: 5 ♂♂ , 6 ♀♀ : Bosnia and Herzegovina , Grebci , Grab (r)ovica pećina cave ( Figs 39–40 ), coordinates 42°44‘37.7“N , 18°03‘27.7“E (WGS 84), 14.06.2005 and 15.04.2009 , D. Čeplík lgt. ( PCDČ , PCJC , PCPH )
.

Remark.
Anthroherpon spelaebatoides
differs from all other species of the genus by the combination of following characters: 1) head slightly wider than pronotum (HW/PW: 1.1–1.2), with relatively deep punctation and dense pubescense ( Fig. 6 ), 2) pronotum shorter than head (HL1/PL:1.3–1.6), without deep constriction in posterior third ( Figs 1 , 10 ), 3) pubescence on pronotal disc relatively dense ( Figs 1 , 10 ), 4) punctation on elytra dense and relatively deep, pubescense dense ( Fig. 1 ), 5) anterior elongation of the mesoepiventrite poorly visible from dorsal aspect of the habitus ( Fig. 1 ) but visible from latero–ventral aspect if venter is free of elytra and pronotum ( Fig. 15 ), 6) mesoventro–mesoepiventral suture relatively well defined ( Fig. 14 ), 7) smaller body size, BL: 3.9–4 mm , 8) AL: 4.3–4.6 mm . Antennae slightly shorter in females. Male antennomeres length (mm): (1) 0.29, (2) 0.13, (3) 0.50, (4) 0.32, (5) 0.41, (6) 0.37, (7) 0.53, (8) 0.36, (9) 0.55, (10) 0.55 and (11) 0.53. Female antennomeres length (mm): (1) 0.35, (2) 0.17, (3) 0.52, (4) 0.34, (5) 0.35, (6) 0.38, (7) 0.46, (8) 0.35, (9) 0.49, (10) 0.44 and (11) 0.50.
Biology : Subterranean species, so far known exclusively from caves.
